extraction_data.summary: 57-year-old male with persistent anterior shoulder pain and biceps tendinopathy who failed conservative management with therapy and injections. Diagnostic arthroscopy revealed an inflamed biceps tendon with fraying at the groove requiring tenodesis, and inflamed bursal tissue was removed from the subacromial space. No rotator cuff tear was identified, and an interference screw was used for fixation.

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L413-L416)

Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) demonstrates labral tear/biceps tendon pathology (e.g., SLAP, Bankart, full-thickness subscapularis tear) and correlates with symptoms and physical exam findings (Evidence: pg no: 10, L417-L420)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

full_source.notes: Conservative management exception for acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L414-L416)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). full_source.notes: Considered medically necessary for ANY of the listed indications when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L301)

full_source.scope: Arthroscopic or open biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L408)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L413-L416)

Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) demonstrates labral tear/biceps tendon pathology (e.g., SLAP, Bankart, full-thickness subscapularis tear) and correlates with symptoms and physical exam findings (Evidence: pg no: 10, L417-L420)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

Resection or transplantation of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L546)

full_source.notes: Conservative management exception for acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L414-L416)

names: Subacromial Balloon Spacers (SABS) (Evidence: pg no: 2, L89)
InSpace™ Subacromial Tissue Spacer System (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90)
Subacromial balloon spacer implantation (SBSI) (Evidence: pg no: 3, L124)
InSpace Biodegradable Subacromial Spacer (Evidence: pg no: 5, L254)
full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Daniel Price
MRN: 784512963
Date of Service: October 2, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Laura Nguyen, MD

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Arthroscopic biceps tenodesis, right shoulder
2. Subacromial bursectomy, right shoulder

INDICATIONS:
57-year-old male with persistent anterior shoulder pain and biceps tendinopathy failing therapy and injections.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Biceps tendinopathy, right shoulder
2. Subacromial bursitis, right shoulder

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Patient placed in beach chair position. Diagnostic arthroscopy showed inflamed biceps tendon with fraying at the groove. The tendon was released from its origin and secured within the bicipital groove via tenodesis technique. Subacromial space was entered and inflamed bursal tissue removed. No rotator cuff tear appreciated.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 50 mL.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
One interference screw utilized for fixation. Brand not documented.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Sling comfort use. Home exercise program initiated. Formal therapy to begin at four weeks focusing on gradual strengthening.
